I'm over 21 Years Old I'm under 21 Years Old Skip to the content The Rum Lab It's Rum Education Time Newscast Interviews Live Streams Global Rum Events Guide Alliances ¡Aquí se habla de Ron! The Ultimate Awards Women Leading Rum Cocktails Rum Guide Understanding what Rum is Find a Rum Society Near You Distilleries around the World Australia Barbados Brazil Canada Colombia Costa Rica Cuba Dominican Republic France Guyana Jamaica Mexico Nicaragua Panamá Puerto Rico United Kingdom United States of America Venezuela Best Rum Livestreams & Youtube Channels Best Rum Podcasts Swag Store About Media Assets Contact US TEAM Join our team Editorial Standards Editorial Guidelines Cookie Policy Sign Up Get featured Search for: Home » Interviews » Eekh Rum, Director & CEO: SIMRAN SINGH Eekh Rum, Director & CEO: SIMRAN SINGH September 24, 2024 Off By Jose Rafael Hoffmann TRL: Who is Simran Singh? I’m Simran Singh, an educator in beverages and a devoted enthusiast of brown spirits. My journey has been about exploring and understanding the intricacies of various alcoholic drinks, and I’m passionate about diving deeper into the alco-bev industry. TRL: What does the rum mean to you? What made you fall in love with rum and when did it happen? Rum is something I’ve grown incredibly passionate about. This interest sparked in 2020 when I was exploring different spirits within the alco-bev segment. Initially, I wasn’t sure about rum as a category, but the more I dug into it, the more it captivated me. Now, I can’t imagine my journey without it. TRL: Three essential characteristics that define the rum according to your perspective. For me, rum is defined by its flavor, color, and age. The flavor of rum can range from sweet and fruity to deep and complex, depending on the ingredients and the distillation process. The color, often influenced by the aging process, gives a visual cue to its depth and character. Finally, age is a crucial factor—it tells the story of the rum, from the barrel to the bottle, and adds layers of sophistication and maturity to the spirit. TRL: What is the most important contribution you have made in the rum industry? One of my proudest contributions is introducing Eekh Agricultural Rum, a unique pure cane spirit, to the Indian market. It’s a one-of-a-kind product that I believe will pave the way for more innovative offerings in the future. And yes, there’s more in the pipeline. TRL: Benefits that the rum industry has given you. The rum industry in India is still relatively unexplored, which means there’s so much potential and so many opportunities to experiment. This space has given me the freedom to innovate and create something that can truly stand out. TRL: What´s  another thing you are passionate about, in addition to rum? Why? Aside from rum, I’ve always been drawn to single malt whiskies from India and around the world. I also have a deep interest in indigenous beverages native to India. There’s still so much to explore in this area, and I’m excited about the possibilities. TRL: What is your favorite place for drinking rum? I don’t have a specific favorite place yet, but I’m always on the lookout for the perfect spot to enjoy a good rum. TRL: Favorite drink + Recipe I’m more of an “on the rocks” person, so my go-to is 60 ml of Eekh Rum over four cubes of ice, or sometimes a single big block of ice. Simple and pure. TRL: Why is it important to educate the rum consumer? India is a huge market for rum, and most consumers aren’t even aware of it. Unfortunately, rum in India has often been underestimated and lumped into the category of cheap or country liquor. Educating consumers about the different types of rum and the quality variations—just like we do with whisky or brandy—can help shift this perception and elevate the status of rum. TRL: Any tips to train the palate and taste a good premium rum? Start by tasting a variety of rums from different regions and aging processes. Take your time to savor the aromas, flavors, and the finish. Pay attention to the subtle notes and how they evolve as the rum breathes. And, of course, always taste with an open mind. TRL: How can the rum contribute to improving the crisis in some countries? Rum production in sugarcane-rich regions has the potential to significantly boost local economies and address socio-economic challenges. In India, states like Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Karnataka could see job creation across the entire supply chain—from sugarcane farming to rum distillation. This not only provides livelihoods but also stimulates related industries, such as transportation, packaging, and marketing. In countries like Jamaica, Cuba, and the Dominican Republic, rum production is an economic cornerstone, offering a stable market for sugarcane and supporting agricultural communities. Additionally, rum distilleries often attract tourism, further driving economic growth by supporting local businesses. On a global scale, the rum industry can promote sustainable agricultural practices, such as organic farming and efficient water use, ensuring long-term viability for both the sugarcane and rum sectors. In economically struggling regions, a thriving rum industry can serve as an economic lifeline, creating jobs, generating revenue, and attracting investment, particularly in rural areas where opportunities are scarce. TRL: Is the commitment to sustainable development the key to success for the permanence of the rum industry in the world? Why? Absolutely. Sustainable development is crucial for the rum industry’s future. By focusing on eco-friendly practices, from sugarcane farming to distillation, the industry can reduce its environmental impact and ensure that it remains viable for generations to come. It’s not just about making great rum—it’s about doing it in a way that respects the planet and the people involved. TRL: Who would like to meet in the rum industry? What would you say to him/her? There are so many people I’d love to meet, but one person who stands out is Ian Burrell, the global ambassador for rum. I’d love to sit down with him, learn from his experiences, and discuss the future of rum. I’d also love to connect with various brand founders, owners, and distillers to exchange ideas and insights. TRL: What are your next goals in the rum industry? I have some exciting plans for the works, but you’ll have to wait and see. I promise it’ll be worth the wait. TRL: Plans you have when you leave the rum industry. I haven’t thought about leaving yet—I’ve just started this journey, and I’m loving every moment. TRL: Why is the role of the bartender important in the rum industry? Bartenders are vital for every spirit, not just rum. When we look back at the 1920s, bartenders were the ones who crafted some of the most iconic rum and bourbon cocktails. Today, though, rum cocktails aren’t as prominent in bars. I’d love to see bartenders experiment more with rum again, reviving those classic cocktails and creating new ones. TRL: What is your advice for new generations in the rum industry? The world of rum is vast and full of untapped potential. As someone passionate about this spirit, I encourage the next generation to dive deep and explore every facet of rum-making. Don’t be afraid to push your boundaries—whether it’s experimenting with unconventional ingredients, aging techniques, or innovative distillation methods. The rum industry thrives on creativity and innovation, and there’s always room for new ideas that challenge the status quo. TRL: How can people learn more about you? Website? Social media page? You can follow me on Instagram to stay updated @therealsim.rum @eekhrum www.eekhrum.com Related posts: Master Distiller and CEO of Destilería de Madrid: JAVIER DOMÍNGUEZ Ruta Maya Rum, Co-Founder & Director: DANILO TERSIGNI About The Author Jose Rafael Hoffmann Creative Director and Concent Manager for EmpresasFH and Director of HOFFMANNdesign. Born and raised in Caracas, Venezuela, Mr. Hoffmann has been one of the most important designers for prestigious companies in South America, including Disney, Cartoon Network, Mattel among others. Owner of Erie's Rum Runners buys bayfront land News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL Owner of Erie's Rum Runners buys bayfront land Ed Palattella epalattella@timesnews.com A mainstay of Erie's bayfront has expanded his reach. A partnership that includes Tim Sedney, who owns Rum Runners Bar and Grill, has purchased the restaurant property as well as two adjacent parcels on East Dobbins Landing -- a storage lot and a bait-shop building that once housed the now-defunct Lund Boat Works. Lake Front Realty, made up of Sedney and his business partner, Gary Liebel, bought the three properties in December for a total of $750,000 from Lund Boat Works Inc. Sedney had been leasing the Rum Runners property from Lund Boat Works, which led to rumors over the years that the lease would soon be up and the bar -- popular among boaters, who can pull up next to it -- would close. With his purchase of the parcel, "Rum Runners will continue on," Sedney said. "Finally, now that I have control of the property, it is a whole different story. We aren't going anywhere." Sedney, 50, also owns Rum Runners Cove, a restaurant in the Sheraton complex on West Dobbins Landing; and co-owns the Lady Kate tour boat, the Scallywags pirate-themed pleasure boat and the O Danny O fishing charter boat. He and Liebel formerly owned the Victorian Princess paddle-wheeler. Sedney said he is considering nonresidential projects for the two other newly purchased parcels, but he declined to detail his ideas because they are not final. "I do have plans," he said. Sedney also had been leasing the other two properties from Lund Boat Works. He had been subletting them to tenants that include Leclair Point, a bait and tackle shop that remains in business in the former Lund Boat Works building. Sedney and his family have a long history with the 1,271-square-foot Rum Runners Bar and Grill and its 0.6-acre lot. His mother, Carol, who died at 73 in 2013, opened Rum Runners there with his father, Jerry Sedney, in 1988. Jerry Sedney died at 51 in 1990, and financial issues caused Carol Sedney to sell the property to Lund Boat Works for $430,000 in 1991, according to county property records. Lund Boat Works and its owner, J. Douglas James, an Erie businessman, immediately leased the property to the Sedney family, who continued to operate Rum Runners. Tim Sedney said he was ready to buy whenever the property went up for sale. "I am absolutely thrilled," he said of the purchase. "It is something I always wanted to do -- get that property back. I am glad it came full circle." He said the purchase includes boat slips behind all the parcels and a boat maintenance and repair building behind Rum Runners. Sedney has been subletting that building to Maritime Marine, which also remains in business there. Lund Boat Works bought the 0.3-acre storage lot for $150,000 from another Erie family in December 1991, and in 1994 bought the 9,000-square-foot former Lund Boat Works building, on 0.3 acres, from the Erie County Industrial Development Authority. The sale price for that building, erected in 1932, was not available in property records. Sedney said he had been leasing that building and the storage lot from Lund Boat Works since shortly after James died in Florida at age 92 in 2011. James' family, no longer in Erie, retained ownership of the properties, and in 2013 decided to offer them to Sedney to buy "and develop as he sees fit," said the lawyer for the James family, Robert Dwyer, of Erie. He said Lund Boat Works stopped operating after James died. The company's founder was celebrated Erie boat builder Herman Lund, who died at 91 in 1981. James, a sailing enthusiast and chief executive of the Erie-based High Pressure Equipment Co., once had ambitious plans for the property on East Dobbins Landing. In 2003, he proposed building a high-rise condominium in conjunction with a proposed commercial and residential development of property the Erie-Western Pennsylvania Port Authority owns on East Dobbins Landing, west of the former Lund Boat Works. The Port Authority project, called McAllister Place, has never proceeded, and neither did James' high-rise, largely because of city ordinances, said the Port Authority's executive director, Brenda Sandberg, who was the city's zoning officer when James proposed his plan. Sandberg said she does not believe the Port Authority had an offer to buy the former Lund Boat Works property. She said she welcomes Sedney's commitment to that area. "It is certainly good," she said. "It is certainly time to see increased development on that property." Sedney said the purchases fit with his family's vision of an expanding waterfront. "I am heavily invested in Erie's bayfront," he said. "We've been around a long time. We've seen a lot of things happen here." ED PALATTELLA can be reached at 870-1813 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at twitter.com/ETNpalattella. About us Front row sunset seats, tasty cocktails and delicious food. Our beautifully designed oceanfront restaurant & cocktailbar are situated on one of the most amazing spots of Bonaire, opposite the uninhabited island of Klein Bonaire. Our menu includes items that are prepared fresh to order. Our servers are friendly and the atmosphere is perfect for dining with friends, family or business associates. Over the past 25+ years Rum Runners has grown by leaps and bounds by holding fast to these simple principles: serve excellent food and cocktails, provide outstanding service and create memorable experiences for our guests.
